channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Chemical Arms Used Repeatedly in Syria, U.N. Says
item.description: Chemical weapons were used repeatedly in the Syria conflict this year, not only in a well-documented Aug. 21 attack but also in four other instances, a United Nations panels said.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Catalonia Clashes With Madrid Over Independence Vote
item.description: Spanish officials immediately rejected a move by a Catalan leader to hold an independence referendum next November.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Room for Debate: Does Europe Need Ukraine?
item.description: Is Kiev a key ally to the European Union, or just a potential trading partner and a buffer against Russia?

item.title: Ukrainian President Meets With Opposition Leaders
item.description: President Viktor F. Yanukovich held his first face-to-face meeting with opposition leaders Friday as the country’s richest man, Rinat Akhmetov, expressed support for the demonstrators.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Mao’s Birth Commemorated in Gold and Gem-Encrusted Statue
item.description: Ahead of the 120th anniversary of his birth, Mao Zedong has been commemorated in a manner befitting China’s modern-day capitalist excesses: a gold, bejeweled statue valued at more than $16 million.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A statue of Mao Zedong commemorating the 120th anniversary of his Dec. 26 birth.

item.title: Crowds Gather for Final Glimpse of Mandela
item.description: After lying in state in Pretoria for three days, his body will be transferred to his childhood village for burial on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN ELIGON and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Mourners waited to view the body of Nelson Mandela in Pretoria on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: New Holiday Schedule Infuriates Many Chinese
item.description: Lunar New Year’s Eve, the most important day in the traditional Chinese calendar, has been excluded from the official holiday schedule for 2014, prompting outrage among many Chinese.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN

item.title: India Ink: Youth Trumps Experience and Wealth in Unlikely Aam Aadmi Party Win
item.description: The victory by Rakhi Birla, the party’s youngest candidate, in the Delhi assembly elections stunned many political observers.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Supporters of the Aam Aadmi Party at a rally in New Delhi on Dec. 11.

item.title: Bits Blog: China Denies Spying on European Diplomats
item.description: A Chinese government spokesman denied accusations by a computer security firm that Chinese hackers were behind computer breaches at five European foreign ministries.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

item.title: 25 Prisoners Flee Baghdad Jail
item.description: Authorities questioned whether guards had helped the prisoners, who were facing terrorism charges, escape.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: North Korean Execution Raises Unease in China
item.description: Bloggers marveled at Jang Song-thaek’s abrupt downfall and violent end, with some drawing parallels with more turbulent periods of recent Chinese history.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: North Korean subway commuters gather around a public newspaper stand in Pyongyang to read about Jang Song-thaek.

item.title: Execution Raises Doubts About Kim’s Grip on North Korea
item.description: The execution of Kim Jong-un’s uncle could signal a fight over the direction of North Korea while sowing concern about the stability of the country.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Jang Song-thaek in Beijing in 2012. North Korea’s state-run news agency said he was killed after being convicted of treason.

item.title: India Ink: Love and Gender, According to the Hindu Epics
item.description: The author argues against the Supreme Court’s contention in its ruling on gay rights that India should be wary of “transplanting Western experience in this country.”
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By DILIP D'SOUZA
item.media:description: "Same Sex Love in India" edited by Ruth Vanita and Saleem Kidwai.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Review for Punk Band Case
item.description: The Russian Supreme Court has ordered a review of the case against two members of the punk band Pussy Riot.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Tobacco Firms’ Strategy Limits Poorer Nations’ Smoking Laws
item.description: The industry is warning countries that their tobacco laws violate an expanding web of treaties, raising the prospect of costly, prolonged legal battles.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:credit: Conor Ashleigh for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cigarette display in Australia, where the tobacco industry lost a case last year. Philip Morris International has filed suit under an investment treaty.

item.title: Trial of an Ex-Premier Raises Tensions in Thailand Further
item.description: Murder charges for a former prime minister and his deputy, connected to a 2010 crackdown on protests, take place against a backdrop of another round of protests.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Bruised by Scandal, British Lawmakers Reject Raise
item.description: Legislators, amid belt-tightening and burdened by their reputation for money-grabbing, are fighting for the right to reject higher pay.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Howick Journal: After Tributes to Mandela the Peacemaker, Recalling Mandela the Fighter
item.description: Mourners have flocked to a small town where a sculpture marks the spot where, in 1962, Nelson Mandela was captured by the apartheid police.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: A sculpture that forms an image of Nelson Mandela’s face at the site where he was captured in 1962 by the apartheid police.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Bomb Hits Security Forces
item.description: A bomb exploded outside a camp for Egyptian security forces in a city along the Suez Canal, killing at least one and wounding more than a dozen others.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Obama Panel Said to Urge N.S.A. Curbs
item.description: A presidential advisory committee’s recommendation of broad new restraints intended to increase privacy protections is a first sign that spying revelations may lead to changes.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Gen. Keith B. Alexander, the director of the National Security Agency, has called the idea of cutting back on spying naïve.

item.title: A Fraud Trial Centers on Not-So-Fine Wine and Sky-High Prices
item.description: Prosecutors say Rudy Kurniawan worked his way into the most rarefied circles of the superrich and made millions selling them counterfeit wine.
item.dc:creator: By MOSI SECRET
item.media:credit: Ricardo DeArantanha/Los Angeles Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rudy Kurniawan participating in a wine-tasting event in Los Angeles in 2005. He is on trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan on charges that he made millions selling counterfeit wines.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Spins Mandela to Fit Its Political Narrative
item.description: In lionizing the former South African president, China’s propaganda authorities have hopscotched over much of Mr. Mandela’s life as they try to write him into a political narrative that burnishes the Communist Party’s legitimacy.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Opposition Leader’s Execution Spurs Protests in Bangladesh
item.description: Abdul Quader Molla, a top opposition leader, is the first person executed as a result of a war-crimes tribunal that has sought to hold people accountable for atrocities committed during the 1971 war for independence.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: North Korea Says Leader’s Uncle Was Executed as a Traitor
item.description: The North said that Jang Song-thaek, the uncle and presumed mentor of Kim Jong-un, was executed for plotting a military coup.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Jang Song-thaek in Beijing in 2012. North Korea’s state-run news agency said he was killed after being convicted of treason.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rogues Are Outlaws No More
item.description: Being an “incorrigible rogue” is no longer against the law in Britain.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
